title: Steelers’ Cameron Heyward hasn’t ruled out skipping games amid contract dispute
description: The four-time All-Pro defensive lineman is seeking a revised contract.
content:
LATROBE, Pa. — Steelers defensive co-captain Cameron Heyward, who has been quietly “holding in” during training camp, broke his silence about his unresolved contract dispute on Monday. After sitting out entirely for the second consecutive practice, Heyward said he hasn’t ruled out skipping games.

“There are definitely options out there that could reflect that,” the 36-year-old Heyward said.

To put the situation in full context, you have to start with last offseason. Heyward had one year left on his contract — a time when the Steelers typically like to negotiate extensions. In 2023, he made $15.85 million in cash, but he counted $22.3M against the cap, according to Over The Cap. The team approached the veteran lineman and asked him to take a pay cut.

Heyward had little leverage. He was coming off an injury-marred 2023 season, during which he was limited to 11 games. Even when he was on the field, Heyward was clearly less than 100 percent, playing through a core muscle injury sustained in camp, as he tallied two sacks and 33 tackles (six for loss).

The negotiation lingered through training camp; it wasn’t until just days before the season-opener that Heyward agreed to a revised three-year, $45 million contract that runs through the end the 2026 season.

“I understand that I signed a contract last year,” Heyward said. “But to be completely honest with you, when I signed that, I told them, ‘When I have an All-Pro year, expect me to come back.’ … I think everybody kind of giggled a little bit. But in my head, I used it as motivation to go out there and prove it.”

Heyward did exactly that, earning All-Pro recognition at 35 years old. Among interior defensive linemen, he finished the 2024 regular season tied for sixth in sacks (eight), fourth in pressures (56, per TruMedia) and fourth in tackles for loss (12). He also had two more batted passes (11) than any other defensive lineman.

On his current deal, which pays him $14.5 million on an average annual basis, he’s the 22nd highest-paid interior defensive lineman, according to Over The Cap. The Chiefs’ Chris Jones makes $31.75 per year, one of 15 interior defensive linemen who will make $20 million or more this year. Heyward said he’s looking to be “valued.”

“When I look at the market and I look at what I’ve done,” Heyward said. “It’s hard to really wrap my head around playing at a number where I’m not even half of what the rest of the market is.”

Heyward said that his representatives reached out to the Steelers in February to begin this process. He’s already been paid $13.45 million in a roster bonus and is set to make $1.3 million in his base salary during the season. He’s set to count $19.65 million against the cap this year. Asked if he’s looking for the Steelers to convert some of his 2026 bonus money ($12.95 million) into guarantees, Heyward acknowledged that’s part of the conversation.

”Being respectful to the process of what both sides are trying to accomplish, I would definitely say that’s something similar I’m thinking about,” he said.

Heyward’s ask isn’t necessarily without precedent. Ahead of the 2004 season, franchise icon Jerome Bettis was similarly approached and asked to take a pay cut. Bettis and the Steelers worked out a one-year, $1 million deal. With incentives, the running back earned $1.4 million in cash, according to Over The Cap.

On that reduced contract, Bettis went on to rush for 941 yards and 13 touchdowns, earning a Pro Bowl nod. Before his final year in 2005, Bettis went back to the Steelers and asked for a raise. According to Bettis, the team slightly bumped his base salary up to $1.5 million. According to Over The Cap, he earned $1.6 million in cash in his final season between base salary and incentives.

While Heyward has not been in uniform the last two practices, he began training camp as a full participant. As camp wore on, he quietly dialed back his participation and was only taking part in individual periods for about a week or so before the news broke of his contract dispute. The team isn’t concerned with the missed practice time.

“I think he’s had like 63,000 (reps) in his career, so he’s probably good,” defensive coordinator Teryl Austin said. “These guys that played a lot of football, they understand our scheme. It’s not like they’re in the new scheme doing something new. So I don’t even worry about that stuff. I don’t give it a second thought.”

Heyward said that he spoke directly with general manager Omar Khan on Monday and that he’s been in contact with owner/team president Art Rooney II and coach Mike Tomlin. It remains to be seen if — and when — the Steelers will meet his demands.

“My goal is to be out here,” Heyward said. “I don’t know what’s going to happen. I’ve had to be honest with myself to be ready for every option. Has it gone the way I wanted it to go? No. If it did, I would be out there playing and practicing. But I’d like to put this in the rearview mirror and worry about ball and worry about the New York Jets Week 1.”
summary: Steelers defensive co-captain, Cameron Heyward, has not been participating in training camp during the dispute over his contract with the team. Despite sitting out for the second consecutive practice, Heyward has not ruled out skipping games. His current deal, which pays him $14.5 million per year, is the 22nd highest-paid interior defensive lineman, with 15 interior defensive linemen expected to make $20 million or more this year. The team had previously approached Heyward to take a pay cut after he was limited to 11 games in the 2023 season due to a core muscle injury. Despite this, he agreed to a revised three-year, $45 million contract that runs through the end of the 2026 season.
shortSummary: Cameron Heyward may skip games due to a contract dispute with the Steelers, aiming to renegotiate his current $14.5 million deal and seek compensation for his injuries.

scraped_sources.text:
LATROBE, Pa. — For the second training camp in a row, Steelers defensive co-captain Cameron Heyward is in a contract dispute.
The 36-year-old interior defensive lineman suited up for the first 12 practices (other than scheduled vet days) and participated in individual drills, but has not taken part in team drills recently. What appeared on the surface to be the Steelers saving a veteran for the regular season can now be characterized as a “hold-in.” Heyward is seeking a revision to his contract, league sources told The Athletic on Thursday.
On Thursday, Heyward did not dress for practice as word of his dispute spread following a report by ESPN. He posted cryptically on Instagram, “When you take things for granted, the things you are granted get taken.”
Cam Heyward is not dressed for practice today pic.twitter.com/xnaFRhcFxF
— Mike DeFabo (@MikeDeFabo) August 7, 2025
Last offseason, Heyward was entering the final year of his contract and was looking for an extension. He had little leverage at the time, as he was coming off a 2023 campaign in which a core muscle injury (and the subsequent surgery) limited him to 11 games. Even when he was on the field in 2023, he was not 100 percent, as he tallied two sacks and 33 tackles (six for loss).
Advertisement
The 2024 training camp negotiations lingered until nearly the 11th hour before Heyward eventually inked a three-year, $45 million deal that runs through the 2026 season.
“Before the season, I told him, ‘Don’t even sign a contract, honestly,’” his brother and Steelers tight end Connor Heyward told The Athletic in January. “Bet on yourself.”
The current contract pays Heyward $14.5 million per season. That’s less on an annual basis than 21 other interior defensive linemen. His production on the field exceeded his paycheck last season, as he earned first-team All-Pro honors for the fourth time in his career.
Among interior defensive linemen, Heyward finished the 2024 regular season tied for sixth in sacks (eight), fourth in pressures (56, per TruMedia) and fourth in tackles for loss (12). He also had two more batted passes (11) than any other defensive lineman. His presence in the middle of the defense was probably the biggest reason the Steelers went from 21st in yards per carry allowed in 2023 (4.3) to fifth-best last year (4.1).
The Steelers drafted defensive tackle Derrick Harmon in the first round of the 2025 draft and Yahya Black in the fifth round to strengthen their defensive front and plan for life after Heyward. However, Heyward is still a key cog of the NFL’s highest-paid defense.
Heyward’s current frustration puts the Steelers in a tough spot. The team has handed out several big-money contracts this offseason, including a three-year contract extension worth $123 million for 30-year-old outside linebacker T.J. Watt and a four-year, $132 million extension for 27-year-old receiver DK Metcalf. They also acquired 30-year-old defensive back Jalen Ramsey, who counts $19.5 million against the cap this year.
The Steelers, who previously were reluctant to give new money to players on the other side of 30, have broken their precedent by signing and acquiring many aging veterans. However, the Steelers need to weigh how much they’re willing to commit to the oldest player on the roster not named Aaron Rodgers. According to OverTheCap.com’s latest projection, the Steelers have an estimated $19.2 million in cap space.
However, the team traditionally likes to save about $10 million for in-season moves and may still be interested in adding a player elsewhere before the season begins.
(Photo: Justin K. Aller / Getty Images)

argos_summary: Cameron Heyward, the Steelers' defensive co-captain, is in a contract dispute as he seeks a revision to his current deal, which pays him $14.5 million annually, making him one of the lower-paid interior defensive linemen despite his All-Pro performance last season. After participating in training camp practices, he has recently scaled back his involvement, indicating he may consider skipping games if his demands are not met. The Steelers face a challenging decision as they balance their salary cap and recent investments in other players while needing to address Heyward's contract situation.
